Description: Lower body and low flaring ring foot sherd of South Ionian pottery cup, probably a cup with everted rim; interior glazed black with two added red rings on floor; exterior glazed above, reserved below: outside of foot glazed, underside reserved; inscription on interior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B1 (possibly)
Curator's comments: The low flaring ring foot of the cup finds parallels with Schlotzhauer's Type 10 cups with everted rim. Type 10 cups were mass produced and include numerous variants. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type V (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Vallet and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B1 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Numerous Type 10 South Ionian cups have been found at Naukratis, as well as in the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra and at Megara Hyblaea on Sicily, and at Berezan on the Black Sea (Posamentir 2006, 165). The place of production of Type 10 South Ionian cups is determined as probably Miletus based on the results of NAA analysis carried out by Hans Mommsen, Bonn, on another sherd (British Museum 1886,0401.1025) from Naukratis and of same shape, decoration, and fabric. The exterior decoration also finds parallels with Hayes' Group I of 'Various East Greek or Cycladic' cups, see no. 1302 in 'Boardman and Hayes 1966, 124-5, fig. 58'.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXII, no. 165)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 655, no. 126)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.236) (Phase 3)
